intro: Angelica wolffiana, commonly known as Wolff's angelica, is a tall biennial or short-lived perennial herb native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its large, compound leaves and showy umbels of white to pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, rich soils along stream banks and in woodland areas. It is valued for its aromatic foliage and has been used historically in herbal medicine. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies and conservation efforts.
